summary: Where do wizards get their groceries? The obviously don’t go to the local muggle shops, because it’s made clear that most have...
body: Where do wizards get their groceries? The obviously don’t go to the local muggle shops, because it’s made clear that most have no idea how to handle muggle money. Are there wizard shops outside of Diagon Alley? Or do they all grow their own food?

reblog.comment: Where do wizards get their groceries? The obviously don’t go to the local muggle shops, because it’s made clear that most have no idea how to handle muggle money. Are there wizard shops outside of Diagon Alley? Or do they all grow their own food?

blog.name: the-headmistress
blog.title: Have a biscuit, Potter.
blog.description:
Before we start the festivities I have a few announcements for our new students: | |
1. This is a fic rec blog for drarry fics, not only for big writers but especially for new ones. | |
So if you're new to the fandom, or simply unrecognised, and need a place to get started, feel free to send me a link to your fic and I'll read it and rec it for you! | |
2. Support and love for new writers is more than welcome! If you don't like what you read, click back—that's why we have the button—and start another one. | |
3. Ship and let ship. Your kink isn't my kink and that's okay. | |
4. Stay out of the forbidden forest, every student who comes out of it alive will be sent straight back home! No exceptions! | |
(If there are too many fics sent our way it's possible we won't find the time to read them all. We are humans with a family, job and life outside the fandom so please keep that in mind.)||
Art by @llap115
http://llap115.tumblr.com

summary:
Title: My Little Berserker
Word count: 105.540
Author: Aelys_Althea
Rating: E 
Warnings: Sort of Bonding, Mild PTSD...
body:
Title: My Little Berserker

Word count: 105.540

Author: Aelys_Althea

Rating: E

Warnings: Sort of Bonding, Mild PTSD Reference

Summary: Eighth year was supposed to be calm. Moderated. Peaceful, even. Draco returned to escape the chaos wrought upon his shambles of a life and Harry to flee the responsibility of a world that sees him as something greater than was truly possible. Hogwarts was a safe haven, right?

At least it was until Hagrid comes up with the wonderful idea to introduce some additional members to the student body of the fluffier variety. Hagrid doesn’t do moderated - where’s the fun in that?

____________________________________

I have no idea where to start, this fic is everything! They have to raise little Foxlet Gliders who choose their ‘parents’. They have to learn to work together else… Read it!

blog.name: bitingdownpromo
blog.title: Biting Down
blog.description: The year is 2027. The wizarding community is tearing itself apart as danger lurks around every corner; the possibility of a wizarding epidemic sends the community into a frenzy that brings a new evil to power. Will you fight for what you believe, or take the path of least resistance?

summary:
the electronics of your heart...
 The year is 2027. Nearly three decades have passed since the battle at Hogwarts and the...
caption:
the electronics of your heart…

The year is 2027. Nearly three decades have passed since the battle at Hogwarts and the wizarding world continues its uphill climb towards a slow, tumultuous recovery. Danger lurks around every corner as the possibility of a wizarding epidemic sends the wizarding community into a frenzy that brings a new evil to power.

see how fast they fall apart…

Will you fight for what you believe, or take the path of least resistance? Whether you flee or bite down and take the heat, the next great war is coming and the outcome is up to you. Welcome to Biting Down.

home | plot | rules | wanted connections | character suggestions | application

blog.name: arnyan
blog.title: The Curse Made Me Do It
blog.description:
Text-based content and dumb memes, that's it, that's my blog. And It's all about Hogwarts Mystery in here.

HPHM Content List

Golden Trio Challenge

summary: Continuation of this Part 1 Are you alright, dear?” Grandma Lee asked, quickly going over to him. He fell onto her and...
body:
Continuation of this Part 1

Are you alright, dear?” Grandma Lee asked, quickly going over to him.

He fell onto her and immediately started bawling again.

The woman immediately wrapped her arms around her grandson and let him cry.

“It’ll be alright dear.” She murmured.

“How are you so sure?” Barnaby sobbed.

“I’m not.” She admitted, holding Barnaby’s tear stained face so she could look him in the eye, “I just know that right now it doesn’t feel like it will ever be fine again, and it probably won’t feel alright for a while, but just know that you’re not alone. You’ve got me, and I’ve got you.”

Barnaby let out a sniff, “You won’t leave me like mother and father?”

“Not when I can help it.” Grandma told him adamantly, “I promise.”

Barnaby’s crying soon subsided.

“I’m scared about what will happen in the future, grandmother.” He confessed, wiping at his face with his hands.

“Then you don’t have to think about it now, Barnaby.” His grandmother replied, taking out her handkerchief and cleaning his face for him.

“We can go as slow as you want.” Grandmother Lee said, “just take everything one day at a time.”

“Really?” The boy asked, his eyes searching for some confirmation.

“Or course,” His grandmother replied, pulling him into another hug.

It was then that Barnaby felt a strange warmth on his face, different from the fireplace.

As he separated from his grandmother to investigate, a bright light hit him right in the eye, making him squint terribly.

“Oh, would you look at that.” His grandmother commented, facing the large bay windows.

Barnaby followed her gaze and immediately squinted again.

“Yes, Barnaby dear,” His grandmother repeated, still watching the window, “We’ll go one day at a time. We will keep going until the day you’re not afraid of tomorrow.”

After a terribly dark day, both grandmother and grandson found themselves sitting side by side on the floor, bathing in the bright sunlight of hope and a better tomorrow.

Fin

blog.name: arnyan
blog.title: The Curse Made Me Do It
blog.description:
Text-based content and dumb memes, that's it, that's my blog. And It's all about Hogwarts Mystery in here.

HPHM Content List

Golden Trio Challenge

summary: Tomorrow 11k Challenge for @delicrieux  Congrats on 11k followers! Barnaby had always liked rainy days. Rainy days meant getting...
body:
Tomorrow

11k Challenge for @delicrieux

Congrats on 11k followers!

Barnaby had always liked rainy days. Rainy days meant getting to sleep in later than usual, they meant having something rich and warm for breakfast, and they meant sitting with his parents by the roaring fireplace as the raindrops pattered against the window panes. It was rainy days like these that he enjoyed.

Unfortunately, that all came to an end on one particularly pouring November day in 1981.

Though he was eight years old at the time, he still couldn’t quite understand what was going on around him.

His grandmother had held his hand the whole time as he watched his parents, for some reason, be yelled at by a whole room of people.

He heard his grandmother muttering things like “Why would they require a young child to be here?” And “Must he witness this?” While angrily glaring at the men and women bombarding his parents with words and phrases he didn’t really get.

What did ‘sentenced to life’ mean?

Why were they saying scary things like ‘death eater’ and ‘he who must not be named’?

At a certain word though, Barnaby’s heart jolted.

Azkaban.

He had heard that word before.

His memory was murky but he swore it had been in the living room that he heard his mother say that word.

It had been night time, perhaps even midnight, and Barnaby had woken up by the sound of his parents loud voices.

He’d gone out of his room to check on them, only to stop right at the top of the stairs when he heard his father swear loudly.

The boy was immediately spooked.

His mother had then said something along the lines of “I-I don’t want to go to Azkaban!”

And to that, his father had responded something like “I don’t think we have a choice.”

And as soon as he had said that, the mansion’s main door burst open and a group of cloaked wizards quickly surrounded his parents.

Barnaby couldn’t really remember what happened after that.

He recalled flashes of going to a big building through the fireplace, a small dark room where some stranger watched him, and hearing his mother’s sobbing from the other room.

His grandmother eventually appeared and took him to her estate, where he stayed in confusion and unease for a few days.

Now they seemed to have gone back to the same big building from before and for some reason, he was now watching his chained up parents being judged by a panel of people.

“Grandmother, what’s going to happen?” He managed to ask, unable to take the suspense anymore.

The look on his grandmothers face when she faced him made him feel all the more like crying.

Her eyes said she was just as unsure as he was.

“Here dear, I brought you this, just read it until everything is done, alright?” She told him, handing him an illustrated children’s book.

Though making a face at his grandmothers evasion of his question, he was still all too relieved to have something to do that even he could understand.

Quietly, Barnaby tried to read the book.

At first he managed to get enchanted by the pictures, only to have his concentration snapped when one particularly old man yelled “Off to Azkaban with them!”

The book fell from Barnaby’s hands as he rushed forward to the barricade that separated him from the floor his parents stood.

A pair of tough looking men had began pulling them towards a door.

“Mother!” Barnaby cried.

His mother’s head snapped towards him, instantly making Barnaby take a step away.

The look on her face both scared and saddened the little boy.

“We’re so sorry, darling.” Mrs Lee croaked. Her voice sounded as broken as she looked.

“Barnaby!” A voice all to familiar to the little boy boomed.

Even after everything, his father still had the same strong and hard tone.

“Remember, you are a Lee!” His father yelled, shoving off the firm hand of the guards from his shoulders, as he rushed closer to his son.

“Whatever you hear, whatever they say, You are a Lee, and that’s not something to be ashamed of!” He growled, struggling to keep his eye contact with his son even when the guards caught up to him and continued to take him through the door.

It was only through his eyes that Barnaby saw the fear and regret his father was hiding from his voice.

“Father!” Barnaby cried.

The door slammed shut, forever marking the last moment Barnaby saw his parents.

Outside the ministry, the rain still hadn’t subsided.

Barnaby and his Grandmother stood at the steps of the disguised government building, apparently waiting for a pick up.

After half an hour of nothing but the noise of the pouring rain, Grandmother Lee announced that they would walk.

Barnaby’s eyes were red from crying in the courtroom. He had ignored the looks of pity and condolences from the very wizards who had sent his parents away and had unabashedly bawled his heart out in front of them.

Now he was tired, heartbroken, and being forced to walk home on such a dark day.

Even the place he called home now wasn’t really home.

His grandmother’s estate may be bigger than his parent’s, but it had felt cold and empty during his short stay there, which would now be permanent it seems.

Looking up at the woman now, he felt slightly guilty for thinking of her house in that way.

She had lost a son today, and he had lost a mother and father.

It was just the two of them left now.

Just as he felt another wave of sadness come over him, a delicious smell entered his nose.

Looking around in surprise, he realized only then that they had been walking through a busy muggle neighborhood.

Even in the slight storm, the streets were bustling and lively.

And this smell, whatever it was, the aroma was so good that his stomach grumbled.

Barnaby had not realized he was hungry until then.

He continued looking around until he spotted it.

There, in a small restaurant with a wooden fish attached to the roof, was where the smell seemed to originate from.

Just as he spotted it, he felt a sudden jerk.

His grandmother had started dragging him towards the shop for some reason.

“Grandmothe-?” Barnaby asked.

“T-two servings please!” His grandmother shakily said. She looked so uncomfortable in the muggle setting that Barnaby was just about to suggest to just go and not bother.

But when he tried to tug at her hand, his grandmother stood steadfast in front of the counter.

“Here you go, ma’am! Enjoy!” The shopkeeper said, handing them a plastic bag with the same delicious aroma wafting out from the top.

“Come along, Barnaby. We better hurry home while they’re hot.” His grandmother chided.

The two managed to get home fast enough that the food was still quite warm.

While Barnaby changed from his damp clothing, His grandmother went about preparing where they were going to eat.

When the boy came down the stairs to the dining room, he was surprised to find it empty.

“In here, Barnaby!” His grandmother’s voice called from the living room.

The closer Barnaby got, the warmer he felt.

When he got there, he was met with a crackling blaze in the fireplace and a grandmother sitting on the rug a short distance in front of it.

“I thought it would be nice to have our meal here.” She said, patting the spot next to her.

Barnaby plopped himself down and looked at the old woman in confusion.

Everything from the muggle shop, to eating on the floor, seemed very out of character of her.

Noticing the boys stare, Grandmother Lee turned to the boy and gave him a smile.

Carefully, grandma Lee took up a French fry and held it out to Barnaby. The little boy took it and and shoved it into his mouth. It had gone a bit soggy from being in the bag too long, but it still felt great having something warm and filling, finally enter his hungry body.

The exhaustion of the day slowly started to fade as he took another fry.

“Here, grandmother.” He offered, holding out a piece of batter covered fried fish.

“Thank you, dear.” His grandmother replied, taking it from him.

The two quietly ate their fish and chips, the sound of the cracking fire, the rain, and the occasional sniff from one of them, filling the silence.

As his grandmother crumpled up the oily newspaper where the food had been wrapped in, Barnaby laid back onto the rug. The feeling of being full making him sleepy.

The moment he closed his eyes though, the picture of his parents’ frightened looks as they were dragged away flashed before his eyes, quickly making the boy sit up and gasp.


Continued below

Part 2

“In here, Barnaby!” His grandmother’s voice called from the living room.

The closer Barnaby got, the warmer he felt.

When he got there, he was met with a crackling blaze in the fireplace and a grandmother sitting on the rug a short distance in front of it.

“I thought it would be nice to have our meal here.” She said, patting the spot next to her.

Barnaby plopped himself down and looked at the old woman in confusion.

Everything from the muggle shop, to eating on the floor, seemed very out of character of her.

Noticing the boys stare, Grandmother Lee turned to the boy and gave him a smile.

Carefully, grandma Lee took up a French fry and held it out to Barnaby. The little boy took it and and shoved it into his mouth. It had gone a bit soggy from being in the bag too long, but it still felt great having something warm and filling, finally enter his hungry body.

The exhaustion of the day slowly started to fade as he took another fry.

“Here, grandmother.” He offered, holding out a piece of batter covered fried fish.

“Thank you, dear.” His grandmother replied, taking it from him.

The two quietly ate their fish and chips, the sound of the cracking fire, the rain, and the occasional sniff from one of them, filling the silence.

As his grandmother crumpled up the oily newspaper where the food had been wrapped in, Barnaby laid back onto the rug. The feeling of being full making him sleepy.

The moment he closed his eyes though, the picture of his parents’ frightened looks as they were dragged away flashed before his eyes, quickly making the boy sit up and gasp.

trail.content_abstract:
Tomorrow

11k Challenge for @delicrieux

Congrats on 11k followers!

Barnaby had always liked rainy days. Rainy days meant getting to sleep in later than usual, they meant having something rich and warm for breakfast, and they meant sitting with his parents by the roaring fireplace as the raindrops pattered against the window panes. It was rainy days like these that he enjoyed.

Unfortunately, that all came to an end on one particularly pouring November day in 1981.
